posts.post_content:
If mythic were around back in Apocalypse, this guy would've been mythic. Above the curve, regenerate, gains counters, and has a sometimes-useful color change...totally mythic.  
  
There's little wonder why he gets played in many BG mid/late game decks.

Posted By: majinara (2/5/2009 3:03:50 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: One of the most powerful creatures ever printed. Not only is he strong for his cost, but you can't chump block him, because he gets bigger. You can't kill him with damage, because he regenerates. You can't use a creature with protection, because he changes color and bypasses that ability. Combine this with support from [Pernicious Deed](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Pernicious Deed), [Maelstrom Pulse](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Maelstrom Pulse) or [Putrefy](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Putrefy), all in-color, and you have a massive threat not many decks have ways of dealing with.
posts.html:
One of the most powerful creatures ever printed. Not only is he strong for his cost, but you can't chump block him, because he gets bigger. You can't kill him with damage, because he regenerates. You can't use a creature with protection, because he changes color and bypasses that ability. Combine this with support from Pernicious Deed, Maelstrom Pulse or Putrefy, all in-color, and you have a massive threat not many decks have ways of dealing with.

Posted By: Equinox523 (5/18/2009 9:20:00 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
He's a beautiful footnote in the world of creature power creep.
  
   
None of the top decks when he was around actually used him, because the environment wasn't suited to playing him, which I think really got the attention of development and was some solid evidence in many arguments about the power of individual cards.
  
   
In my world, casual kitchen table magic, he is an extremely rarely seen overpowered but acceptable card. I personally don't want cards like this made and it makes me sad that there are 5 drop creatures as powerful as him at mythic and rare nowadays (like baneslayer). But he isn't BROKEN. He's just a really good creature.
posts.html:
He's a beautiful footnote in the world of creature power creep.

None of the top decks when he was around actually used him, because the environment wasn't suited to playing him, which I think really got the attention of development and was some solid evidence in many arguments about the power of individual cards.

In my world, casual kitchen table magic, he is an extremely rarely seen overpowered but acceptable card. I personally don't want cards like this made and it makes me sad that there are 5 drop creatures as powerful as him at mythic and rare nowadays (like baneslayer). But he isn't BROKEN. He's just a really good creature.

Posted By: niallcmurray86 (7/9/2010 12:46:34 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Still sees play in Rock decks; though I've moved mine out for [Primeval Titan](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Primeval Titan) recently; mostly because [Plows](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Plows).  
  
I always thought he was cool as heck; and he doesn't break the bank. Fact is; if they \*don't\* have sac/exile on hand, he's a very fast clock and blocking him shortens that clock potentially.  
  
G/B was treated good at the time (This, [Deed](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Deed), [Plague Spitter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Plague Spitter) etc..) so with the resurgence of G/B being powerful in tournies ([Deathrite](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Deathrite), [Abrupt Decay](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Abrupt Decay), [Maelstrom Pulse](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Maelstrom Pulse), etc..) he can still be used.  
  
If it turns out I have enough enchant/arty hate I'll probably go back to using him as a 2-of. Regenerators are sometimes nasty to deal with; and one that's this hard to kill and this huge makes it all the more important.  
  
Unlike most regenerators, he's not susceptible to -X/-X most of the time, and -1/-1 counters will eventually go away. (Good luck ca... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
Still sees play in Rock decks; though I've moved mine out for Primeval Titan recently; mostly because Plows.

I always thought he was cool as heck; and he doesn't break the bank. Fact is; if they *don't* have sac/exile on hand, he's a very fast clock and blocking him shortens that clock potentially.

G/B was treated good at the time (This, Deed, Plague Spitter etc..) so with the resurgence of G/B being powerful in tournies (Deathrite, Abrupt Decay, Maelstrom Pulse, etc..) he can still be used.

If it turns out I have enough enchant/arty hate I'll probably go back to using him as a 2-of. Regenerators are sometimes nasty to deal with; and one that's this hard to kill and this huge makes it all the more important.

Unlike most regenerators, he's not susceptible to -X/-X most of the time, and -1/-1 counters will eventually go away. (Good luck ca... (see all)

posts.post_content:
The original Baneslayer Angel.   
  
But remember guys, his true cost is ![3](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=3&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol). Unless you want to tap out and leave your spiritmonger vulnerable. Titans effect the battlefield even if they are [Oblivion Ring](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Oblivion Ring) / [Path to Exile](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Path to Exile), this guy does not. With so much white removal floating around in the tournament scene, that would be a good reason why this guy does not see competitive play.  
Still an awesome creature even to this day.
